area.title: Foundations of New Sociotechnical Systems
area.description: Over the decades, social media platforms have come and gone, but all share some fundamental building blocks. We examine these patterns to rethink how digital spaces function. By altering their underlying “physics,” we can unlock new ways for people to communicate and share.

area.title: Participatory Governance
area.description: Most online platforms, online communities, and AI systems are governed in a top-down manner. But in the offline world, alternative governance structures abound, including more participatory ones. Drawing from offline institutional design, we build tools and workflows to enable participatory governance of digital institutions.

area.title: Improving Online Discourse
area.description: Online spaces for conversation can be notorious for being toxic, hateful, misinformed, or just unproductive. We build tools to encourage higher quality conversations, including more informative and more empathetic ones. We also build tools to  guard against harassment in ways that are customizable to user and community needs.

area.title: Public Interest and Deliberative Tech
area.description: A healthy public sphere depends on the efforts of people working in the public interest---from journalists, to online volunteers, to researchers and scientists, to public communicators. We build tools to support public interest workers and amplify their efforts. We also build technology to strengthen and support the goals of traditional civic institutions.

area.title: Tools for Thought and Creativity
area.description: Technology and human production have always been intertwined. But with increasingly advanced tools, what constitutes ownership and what demands attribution? When can tools help us work better and when should they get out of our way? We design new tools to support group collaboration, critical thinking and reflection, sensemaking, and creative work.

area.title: Socially Situated AI
area.description: AI capabilities are rapidly advancing---but for these systems to truly make a positive impact on our society, we must build them with social awareness and govern them with all of society in mind. We work on AI systems that engage with subjectivity, uncertainty, and nuance in principled and understandable ways, and that are reponsive to user and community values.
